title: How to Make Onion Ring Batter

steps.headline: Sift the flour into a large mixing bowl.
steps.description: Add a pinch of salt. Make a well in the center of the sifted flour.

steps.headline: Tip the egg yolks and oil into the well.
steps.description: Use a large spoon or electric mixer to mix until smooth. Gradually add the milk while mixing, and beat well.

steps.headline: Cover the batter.
steps.description:
Let stand for 30 minutes in the refrigerator, to chill. While the batter is sitting, slice the onion rings to about 1/2 inch/1cm thickness. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2c\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2c\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: After 30 minutes, whisk the egg white until stiff.
steps.description: Fold into the batter.

steps.headline: Dip the onion rings into the batter and fry until golden brown.
steps.description: This will take about 3-4 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove from the oil using tongs or a slotted spoon.
steps.description: Place on kitchen paper to remove any excess grease, then serve immediately.

steps.headline: Pour the lager or beer of choice into a large mixing bowl.
Whisk in the flour gradually.
steps.description:
Whisk until it turns smooth and silky in consistency. Add more flour if needed but only after whisking to see if it's enough or not. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/fa\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/fa\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Add the cayenne pepper, soy sauce and seasoning to taste.
steps.description: Mix through well.

steps.headline: Place in the refrigerator to chill before using.
steps.description: Thirty to sixty minutes is a good amount of time.

steps.headline: While chilling, prepare the onion rings.
steps.description: Cut into 1/2 inch/1 cm rings and place in the refrigerator to chill.

steps.headline: Cook the onion rings.
Remove with tongs or a slotted spoon.
steps.description: Place on kitchen paper to drain any excess oil.

steps.headline: Serve immediately for best flavor.
steps.description:
Season again if needed. Salsa, tomato ketchup, mayonnaise, etc. make good accompaniments. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2f\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2f\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 400ºF/200ºC.
Slice the onion rings 1/2 inch/1 cm thick.
steps.description: Place in the refrigerator while making the batter.

steps.headline: Mix 1/2 cup flour with enough liquid to turn it runny and smooth.
steps.description: It should stick to the back of a spoon thinly.

steps.headline: Mix together the breadcrumbs, cheese, red pepper flakes and oregano.
steps.description: Season with salt and pepper to taste.

steps.headline: Put 2 tablespoons of flour inside a paper bag.
steps.description: Add the onion rings and toss until well coated. (Don't overfill the bag, toss a few at a time, checking if it needs a refill of flour after each toss.)

steps.headline: Dip each onion ring individually into the batter.
steps.description: Shake off any excess, gently.

steps.headline: Arrange the dipped rings in a single layer across a parchment covered baking sheet.
steps.description: Continue dipping each ring and arranging until all are done.

steps.headline: Place in the preheated oven.
steps.description: Bake for 20-25 minutes or until golden brown. Check after 10-12 minutes. Use tongs to flip over each ring to ensure good browning on both sides.

steps.headline: Remove from the oven.
steps.description: Serve immediately with a dipping sauce and other relevant food.

steps.headline: Slice the onion into thin rings.
Place the rings across a wide dish.
steps.description: Pour the milk over the top and leave to sit for half an hour.

steps.headline: Pour the flour and seasoning onto a plate.
steps.description: Mix to combine.

steps.headline: Pour the oil into a wok or deep frying pan/skillet.
steps.description: Heat the oil until it reaches 350ºF/180ºC.

steps.headline: Dip each ring in the seasoned flour mix on the plate.
steps.description: Place in the deep oil and fry until golden brown, about 3-4 minutes.

steps.headline: Place on kitchen paper towel to drain.
Serve immediately.

tyn: Large mixing spoon or handheld electric mixer
Deep frying container or large skillet/heavy based frying pan with high rims
Tongs or spatula for turning rings over when baking
text:
Basic unseasoned batter Sift the flour into a large mixing bowl. Add a pinch of salt. Make a well in the center of the sifted flour. Tip the egg yolks and oil into the well. Use a large spoon or electric mixer to mix until smooth. Gradually add the milk while mixing, and beat well. Cover the batter. Let stand for 30 minutes in the refrigerator, to chill. While the batter is sitting, slice the onion rings to about 1/2 inch/1cm thickness. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2c/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} After 30 minutes, whisk the egg white until stiff. Fold into the batter. Dip the onion rings into the batter and fry until golden brown. This will take about 3-4 minutes. Remove from the oil using tongs or a slotted spoon. Place on kitchen paper to remove any excess grease, then serve immediately. Beer batter Pour the lager or beer of choice into a large mixing bowl. Whisk in the flour gradually. Whisk until it turns smooth and silky in consistency. Add more flour if needed but only after whisking to see if it's enough or not. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fa/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Add the cayenne pepper, soy sauce and seasoning to taste. Mix through well. Place in the refrigerator to chill before using. Thirty to sixty minutes is a good amount of time. While chilling, prepare the onion rings. Cut into 1/2 inch/1 cm rings and place in the refrigerator to chill. Cook the onion rings. Pour enough oil to cover in a heavy based frying pan with high sides or use a deep fryer. Drop each ring into seasoned flour and coat well. The dip in the batter. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c9/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Using tongs, dunk into the hot oil. Fry until golden brown, about 3-4 minutes. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b4/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Remove with tongs or a slotted spoon. Place on kitchen paper to drain any excess oil. Serve immediately for best flavor. Season again if needed. Salsa, tomato ketchup, mayonnaise, etc. make good accompaniments. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Spicy baking batter Preheat the oven to 400ºF/200ºC. Slice the onion rings 1/2 inch/1 cm thick. Place in the refrigerator while making the batter. Mix 1/2 cup flour with enough liquid to turn it runny and smooth. It should stick to the back of a spoon thinly. Mix together the breadcrumbs, cheese, red pepper flakes and oregano. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Put 2 tablespoons of flour inside a paper bag. Add the onion rings and toss until well coated. (Don't overfill the bag, toss a few at a time, checking if it needs a refill of flour after each toss.) Dip each onion ring individually into the batter. Shake off any excess, gently. Arrange the dipped rings in a single layer across a parchment covered baking sheet. Continue dipping each ring and arranging until all are done. Place in the preheated oven. Bake for 20-25 minutes or until golden brown. Check after 10-12 minutes. Use tongs to flip over each ring to ensure good browning on both sides. Remove from the oven. Serve immediately with a dipping sauce and other relevant food. Crunchy milk batter Slice the onion into thin rings. Place the rings across a wide dish. Pour the milk over the top and leave to sit for half an hour. Pour the flour and seasoning onto a plate. Mix to combine. Pour the oil into a wok or deep frying pan/skillet. Heat the oil until it reaches 350ºF/180ºC. Dip each ring in the seasoned flour mix on the plate. Place in the deep oil and fry until golden brown, about 3-4 minutes. Place on kitchen paper towel to drain. Serve immediately.
sentences: Basic unseasoned batter Sift the flour into a large mixing bowl.
Add a pinch of salt.
Make a well in the center of the sifted flour.
Tip the egg yolks and oil into the well.
Use a large spoon or electric mixer to mix until smooth.
Gradually add the milk while mixing, and beat well.
Cover the batter.
Let stand for 30 minutes in the refrigerator, to chill.
While the batter is sitting, slice the onion rings to about 1/2 inch/1cm thickness.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2c\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2c\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} After 30 minutes, whisk the egg white until stiff.
Fold into the batter.
Dip the onion rings into the batter and fry until golden brown.
This will take about 3-4 minutes.
Remove from the oil using tongs or a slotted spoon.
Place on kitchen paper to remove any excess grease, then serve immediately.
Beer batter Pour the lager or beer of choice into a large mixing bowl.
Whisk in the flour gradually.
Whisk until it turns smooth and silky in consistency.
Add more flour if needed but only after whisking to see if it's enough or not.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/fa\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/f\/fa\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-8Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Add the cayenne pepper, soy sauce and seasoning to taste.
Mix through well.
Place in the refrigerator to chill before using.
Thirty to sixty minutes is a good amount of time.
While chilling, prepare the onion rings.
Cut into 1/2 inch/1 cm rings and place in the refrigerator to chill.
Cook the onion rings.
Pour enough oil to cover in a heavy based frying pan with high sides or use a deep fryer.
Drop each ring into seasoned flour and coat well.
The dip in the batter.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c9\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/c\/c9\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Using tongs, dunk into the hot oil.
Fry until golden brown, about 3-4 minutes.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b4\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b4\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-12Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Remove with tongs or a slotted spoon.
Place on kitchen paper to drain any excess oil.
Serve immediately for best flavor.
Season again if needed.
Salsa, tomato ketchup, mayonnaise, etc.
make good accompaniments.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2f\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2f\/Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-Onion-Ring-Batter-Step-14Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Spicy baking batter Preheat the oven to 400ºF/200ºC.
Slice the onion rings 1/2 inch/1 cm thick.
Place in the refrigerator while making the batter.
Mix 1/2 cup flour with enough liquid to turn it runny and smooth.
It should stick to the back of a spoon thinly.
Mix together the breadcrumbs, cheese, red pepper flakes and oregano.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Put 2 tablespoons of flour inside a paper bag.
Add the onion rings and toss until well coated.
(Don't overfill the bag, toss a few at a time, checking if it needs a refill of flour after each toss.)
Dip each onion ring individually into the batter.
Shake off any excess, gently.
Arrange the dipped rings in a single layer across a parchment covered baking sheet.
Continue dipping each ring and arranging until all are done.
Place in the preheated oven.
Bake for 20-25 minutes or until golden brown.
Check after 10-12 minutes.
Use tongs to flip over each ring to ensure good browning on both sides.
Remove from the oven.
Serve immediately with a dipping sauce and other relevant food.
Crunchy milk batter Slice the onion into thin rings.
Place the rings across a wide dish.
Pour the milk over the top and leave to sit for half an hour.
Pour the flour and seasoning onto a plate.
Mix to combine.
Pour the oil into a wok or deep frying pan/skillet.
Heat the oil until it reaches 350ºF/180ºC.
Dip each ring in the seasoned flour mix on the plate.
Place in the deep oil and fry until golden brown, about 3-4 minutes.
Place on kitchen paper towel to drain.
Serve immediately.
